Ern≈ë Nemecsek, in the book, is portrayed as a courageous yet physically not very strong boy who is deeply committed to his friends and their group, known as the "Paul Street Boys." As a low-ranking member, he is treated as a common soldier with no special rights or position like the officers have. Despite this, he is depicted as an incredibly honest and loyal character, deeply concerned about his friends' opinions, especially Boka, one of the group's leaders.

Nemecsek faces a misunderstanding or mistake that labels him a "traitor," deeply affecting him because honor and loyalty to his friends are paramount to him. Being written in the "black book" with his name in lowercase letters symbolizes the stigma and emotional distance from the group attributed to him.

Nevertheless, Nemecsek does not give up and strives to clear his name and prove his loyalty and bravery. This effort to prove his innocence and regain his status within the group is a significant part of his character development throughout the book. He emerges as a deeply emotional, committed, and brave boy ready to defend his honor and restore his relationship with his friends, in a world where friendship and loyalty are among the highest values.
